131.42.text:
We'd been in Bundy working on
Delos for about a month now.

135.54.text:
With our systems in order and
stock of food, we were ready to
say good-bye

139.55.text:
and start our 700 mile sail
north to Cairns

156.05.text:
"First sail out, left Bundaberg
an hour and half ago..

180.52.text:
"Got our sails up...cruising...
on our way to Lady Musgraves!

204.89.text:
There's nothing like shaking
out the sails, and seeing em
fill

208.92.text:
And it'd been nearly a year
since I parked Delos to work

213.10.text:
then I realised how much I
missed sailing, but suddenly
the fresh breeze struck me in
the face

217.28.text:
and Delos started that gentle
motion that takes over a boat
at sea

225.44.text:
I remember the tough sail we
had coming down the coast last
year fighting the swells and
breeze

229.52.text:
Just beating and beating into
the nasty south-east on our way
to Bunderberg

233.71.text:
Fighting for each mile as we
tacked back and forth

242.00.text: But no we're going the right way

250.36.text:
We crossed over our zig zags of
tacks that took us 24 hours in
a single afternoon

279.07.text:
We even had our first dolphin
sighting as a pod came in and
played in Delos bow wave for a
few minutes

291.42.text:
And as we neared the protective
atoll that forms that southern
most tip of the

295.45.text:
Great Barrier Reef, we were
welcomed by a sweet rainbow

303.62.text:
The pass at Musgrave is not a
large one, but at least it's
well marked

307.63.text:
Still, it's always a little
sketchy at closed quarters

328.14.text:
It's isolated from the mainland
and has some strange bird
eating tree's

332.17.text:
Apparently the tree's capture
their prey in sticky sap

336.34.text:
And absorb the nutrients as
they decompose

340.49.text:
Science warn against trying to
save stricken birds

344.67.text:
It's best to just let nature
take it's course

365.04.text:
But we weren't here for the
birds, our mission was pretty
clear

369.06.text:
Test out the boat systems, a
sort of mini-shake down cruise

373.08.text:
to see what was in order and
what wasn't, so we decided to
crank up the compressor

377.13.text:
And do a dive to test all our
gear

418.29.text:
Our first dive was about as
simple and easy as it gets

422.46.text:
Right off Delos, and down to
the sandy bottom that makes
Musgrave such a great anchorage

438.88.text:
About the most exciting thing
we found was our anchor

443.03.text:
set nicely in the good holding
sandy bottom

447.06.text:
with our test dive a success,
we headed out of the pass to
get a look at the outer reef

451.17.text:
which definitely had better
coral and fish life

500.42.text:
We didn't linger too long at
Musgrave

504.48.text:
With good wind and weather, we
were eager to get to the
Whitsundays and continue our
trip north

533.25.text:
(softly screams)
"I'm a bit scared of heights"

537.28.text:
"Just found out today, hanging
on a * * * *ing swinging mast!"

570.17.text:
The breeze was out of the
south-east and we were in for
more down-wind sailing

574.50.text:
so we set the poles and hoisted
both forward sails

628.28.text: Not to be outdone by my brother,

632.33.text:
I decided to go up the main
mast under sail to see if I
could get some good footage

644.96.text:
If the tiniest swell gets
magnified by the height of
Delos 20 metre mast

648.99.text:
So at the top, you're swinging
wildly back and forth. It was
still pretty cool though!

653.04.text:
I'd definitely do it again.
Maybe in smaller swells next
time

685.84.text:
On our second day of sailing,
we hooked our first fish of the
trip!

689.88.text:
A mouth-watering delicious big
eye tuna

714.53.text:
Nothing beats tuna this fresh!
So fresh, you don't even need
to chew.

718.71.text:
Just let the savoury meat
dissolve right on your tongue

734.94.text:
The 350 mile sail to the
Whitsunday's was a dream

739.11.text:
A perfect, constant 20 breeze
to our back, and clear blue
skies

759.94.text:
We arrived in the early
afternoon

763.97.text:
and spent some cruising cash on
a few nights in the Hamilton
Island Marina

768.04.text:
where we'd stayed for a few
months on our trip south last
season.

788.53.text:
We met up with some old mates
that still worked on the island
and had a bit of a rager.

813.24.text:
We slept it off by taking lot's
of hot showers and napping at
the pool.

821.47.text: With our Hammo mission a success

825.64.text:
we threw off the dock lines and
for the first time of the trip
motored in calm waters.

842.08.text:
Our next stop was Hayman island
where we decided to go ashore
and stretch our legs after the
sail from Hamilton.

854.28.text:
The flora and fauna was pretty
cool, including these little
guys who were very skittish.

866.43.text:
We took some time to enjoy the
afternoon sun, and watch Delos
swing back and forth

870.47.text:
on her hook in the ever present
south easterlies.

911.50.text: "And then we got off the dock,

915.67.text:
went to Haymond Island, had a
really cool sunset hike

919.85.text:
chilled out there, it was
beautiful flat calm

923.92.text:
woke up this morning to a good
30 knots of breeze

928.10.text:
so decided it was time to start
sailing

932.13.text:
and now we're headed out to
Bait Reef

940.27.text:
if it's not too windy and
choppy maate

944.29.text:
and then north to Cairns to
pick up the Josje Rama's"

960.75.text:
The fresh breeze was kicking up
quite a swell and we were
moving along nicely.

969.10.text:
We were definitely having a
better time of it then these
guys.

973.36.text:
They even left their fenders
down!

993.99.text:
We dove at Bait Reef last year
on our way south and were keen
to get back in the water at
this beautiful spot.

998.15.text:
An especially cool feature are
the giant trevally and wrasses

1002.23.text:
that congregate right under
your boat.

1018.76.text:
Knowing Delos would be safe on
the mooring we headed off for
some exploring.

1031.14.text:
It paid off right away when
Brady found a dive light, still
in working condition!

1067.97.text:
The swim throughs and coral are
pretty cool here

1072.13.text:
but what really stands out is
the fish life.

1080.42.text:
that is nearly as large as you
are!

1109.16.text:
so graceful even with the crazy
chameleon like eyes.

1113.24.text:
Always looking for a handout,
but that's what makes the fish
here so approachable.

1146.10.text:
With Josje's flight into Cairns
only a few days off,

1150.28.text:
..we pressed north. More
beautiful days, more downwind
sailing.

1158.57.text:
..just drifting along on the
steady breeze with the sun on
your back.

1162.60.text:
Days, and hundreds of miles,
just melt away.

1179.02.text:
Always eager to stretch our
legs after a long sail,

1183.10.text:
we ventured ashore to check out
the old WWII fort at the top of
the island.

1199.41.text:
During the height of the war
the Australian army built

1203.44.text:
gunnery emplacements to
protect crucial harbors from
attack.

1207.61.text:
Most of the gun mounts and
buildings are still preserved
and make awesome exploring.

1236.42.text:
We hoisted sail to complete the
last overnight

1240.44.text:
portion of our sail from
Bundaberg to Cairns.

1244.49.text:
We'd come so far so quickly,
taking about two weeks

1248.52.text:
to cover the 700 miles between
ports.

1252.69.text:
Delos had proven herself as
cruise ready, and we had too.

1273.16.text:
Up next- Josje-Rama is back on
the scene!

1277.18.text:
And the crew lives it up in
backpacker central!
